Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2014 Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang/InField) will be held at The University of Texas at Arlington in June and July 2014. The Institute provides critical training to generate more and better fieldwork as a response to the global crisis of language endangerment. As a result, a wide variety of audiences become trained in a multi-faceted set of skills in community-centered language documentation. Instructors come from the international community of indigenous and academic experts to provide state-of-the-art, intensive training. Participants include undergraduate and graduate students, practicing linguists, and members of indigenous communities. With prior Institutes held in 2008 (University of California, Santa Barbara), 2010 (University of Oregon), and 2012 (University of Kansas), the Institute has a developed a significant track record of national and international success, drawing an audience from the United States, Canada, and at least twenty other countries. Previous participants have parlayed their Institute experiences into successful fieldwork ventures and community documentation projects worldwide.

The Institute consists of two parts, lasting six weeks total. First, two weeks of intensive workshops focus on the practice and principles of documentary linguistics, ranging from new technology to interdisciplinary methods to best practices in ethical community collaborations. Following that, the Institute offers an optional four weeks of intensive field methods courses focused on several different endangered languages. These integrate the technology and documentation skills acquired during the preceding workshops. The entire six-week Institute thus offers those new to fieldwork the opportunity to put into practice the newly-acquired methods, technical skills, and collaborative approaches.

Given the rapid changes in technological tools and methodologies, even since the first Institute in 2008, the 2014 Institute offers the opportunity for participants and instructors to acquire and share cutting-edge knowledge in language documentation, to network with experts and possible collaborators, and to document endangered languages onsite in the field methods classes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The "2014 Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang/InField)"  (NSF BCS-1263939) funded the 2014 iteration of the Institute on Collaborative Language Research.  CoLang is the premier training venue for language documentation and revitalization in North America.  CoLang 2014 occurred June 16-25, 2014 with the field methods practicum scheduled just after the main Institute, from June 30-July 25, 2014. By attending CoLang, participants learned new methods and technologies for language documentation and revitalization; built skills in collaborative community work; network with field linguists and indigenous scholars from all over the world; and worked with indigenous languages of the Americas and Africa to acquire documentary skills in practice by firsthand documentation of the practicum language.

The intellectual merit occurred in several domains.  First, the two weeks of intensive training and discussion fostered collaborative and technological skills. Second, the workshops generated instructional resources and materials (being compiled centrally by the CoLang 2020/2022 organizers at the University of Montana) as well as new and improved Linguistics Resources following/as a result of attending CoLang 2014.  Finally, CoLang advances knowledge through the inclusion of diverse perspectives, research questions and epistemologies as a result of having recruited and hosted faculty and students from diverse countries, diverse backgrounds (including race and ethnicity), and diverse theoretical frameworks in linguistics.

In terms of the broader impacts, this award has produced both direct and indirect broader impacts and benefit to society. First, it resulted in improved processes of collaboration, quality of materials, and analysis of data. Second, by disseminating existing technologies knowledge beyond attendees, it enhanced research infrastructure in the language sciences.  Third, it trained linguistic students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels and also underserved indigenous communities, including Native Americans and others.

The outcomes of CoLang 2014 include its major activities. The Institute had nearly 200 people in attendance as participants/students, instructors or those giving public talks. The practicum languages were Alabama (a Muskogean language spoken in Texas); Innu (an Algonquian language spoken in Quebec, Canada); Apoala Mixtec (an Oto-Manguean language spoken in Oaxaca, Mexico) and Ngambay (a Central Sudanic Nilo-Saharan language spoken in Cameroon and Chad. Twenty-seven different indigenous communities from the Americas were in attendance. With regard to international attendees, at least 11 other countries were in attendance with at least one representative, including: Australia, Canada, Ethiopia, Iraq, Japan, Kenya, Nigeria, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and Thailand. In total attendance and total number of indigenous American communities represented exceeded the three previous institutes. The curriculum offerings included nearly sixty courses, ranging from technology to immersion teaching methods to linguistically-focused approaches to documenting language. The offerings and number of participants at CoLang 2014 exceeded previous institutes. Four-day CoLang courses included: Advanced ELAN Techniques, Audio 1, Audio 2, Community Language Archives, Data Management and Archiving, FLEx 1, FLEx 2, ELAN 1, ELAN 2, Grant-Writing, Introduction to Linguistics 1, Introduction to Linguistics 2, Language and Wellness, Lexicography, Life in Communities, Orthography, Pedagogical Grammars, Principles of Database Design, Song Documentation, Survey Methods, Teaching Methods for Indigenous Languages, Transcription. Two-hour CoLang courses included: Personal Well Being in Minority Language Communities, and Service-Learning in Linguistics. Public events were also scheduled and brought publicity and attendance from beyond the participants.  One such event was a screening of Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope, recorded in the Navajo language.

 

Three publications resulted from CoLang 2014 activities, as well as a plenary given at the Linguistic Society of America Annual Meeting in 2017:

Publications:

Fitzgerald, Colleen M. 2016. "Morphology in the Muskogean Languages," Language and Linguistics Compass, v.10, 2016, p. 681. doi:10.1111/lnc3.12227 

Fitzgerald, Colleen M. 2017. "Motivating the Documentation of the Verbal Arts: Arguments from Theory and Practice," Language Documentation & Conservation 11, p. 114. doi:http://hdl.handle.net/10125/24628 

Fitzgerald, Colleen M. 2018. "Creating sustainable models of language documentation and revitalization." Insights from practices in community-based research: From theory to practice around the globe ed. by Shannon Bischoff and Carmen Jany, 94-111. Berlin: De Gruyter Mouton.


Plenary address:
Colleen M. Fitzgerald. "The Sounds of Indigenous Language Revitalization.," Linguistic Society of America Annual Meeting, 2017. doi:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wrPe_6KdoOo
